title: Magnetic Hex Tile Holder for Eclipse

description.text: I took the saiyanslayer's part as inspiration and designed my own using FreeCAD (source file included, feel free to modify). I use 3x1mm neodym magnets from ebay (10$ incl. shipping for 500 pcs).

Make a test print first and adapt scaling of the tolerances are too tight. I use 0.2mm layer height for speed. Let the part cool down long enough so it will not warp. Press in a magnet on each side (with alternating polarity of course, otherwise you'll have a problem). Fix the magnets with a drop of CA glue if they are loose. I used different a different color for the 7 tiles in the center (001 and 1xx).

description.text:
On February 26th, 2015, two llamas went on the run from authorities in one of the most thrilling chases ever captured by social media. It is with great pride I present this #TeamLlama 3D printable coaster / wall hang.  
Print this out and use it to set your drink on, or, tack it to your way. When people see it, it will start an immediate conversation about where YOU were when the great llama chase of 2015 happened.

This was a really simple one to make. it's 4.8mm thick, with the #TeamLlama cut-out lettering reaching a depth of 2.4mm. The model itself fits within the bounds of a 4" square.  
You can print in all of one color, or, perhaps print the bottom 2.4mm in one color while printing the top 2.4mm in another color? Just a thought.
soap dish prints in mm

This is an Art Deco style lampshade designed to fit a standard US lamp socket.  Printed in "clear" ABS it works well with a 4.5 watt ("40 watt" output) LED bulb.  
UPDATE: please use version 3 of the top section.  I've also uploaded the matching scad file.

All three pieces are designed for spiral printing.  
Print the body and top section slowly, particularly watching at the end to avoid (as much as possible) overheating at the tips.  
The top section has a cylinder in the center which will need to be trimmed down to allow the bulb to fit.  It is left long in the model to serve as support during printing.  
Print the connector at whatever speed you desire with the top and bottoms turned off.  It is just a tube.  
The connector will be a tight fit.  Carefully insert it into the top section, pushing it all the way up so it rests against the flutes.  Mount the top section onto your lamp holder, insert the bulb, and then carefully work the main body onto the connector.  Some twisting may help to close up the gap (since the spiral on the connector acts a bit like a thread).  
I printed everything on my Rostock Max v2 with a 0.4mm nozzle at 0.8mm width and 0.2mm layer height.    The examples were sliced using Cura.  I'm unsure if the other slicers will handle the incomplete base of the top and body sections.  Watch out for that if you use another slicer, you want a 76.6mm hole in the bottom of each part.  
USE CAUTION the first time you assemble and turn this thing on.  Don't just flip in the switch and walk out of the room.  Hang around a while until you understand how much heat your particular setup will generate and you feel that the thing isn't going to melt or, worse yet, burst into flames.  Don't be an idiot.  Also, it should go without saying that it PROBABLY IS NOT A GOOD IDEA to use this with an incandescent bulb...again, don't be an idiot.  
If you do run into heat issues, you could probably cut some holes in the top and bottom to provide better ventilation.  Baffles could be added inside (just loose, sitting on the steps) to avoid light "beams" from spoiling the look.  I haven't tried this, but it seems like it would work.  The bulb I'm using seems to reject a bunch of heat though the edison socket itself, which works out really well with this design, since the body of the lamp holder is outside the plastic pieces.

In order to maximize thermal transfer between the resistors and thermal block, the contact area between them must be maximized by making both surfaces as flat as possible. I was introduced to this trick through PC modding, more information can be found by googling "heat sink lapping." The picture of the resistors is to show that they are certainly not flat on the bottom, when the process is complete the surface should look uniform but not necessarily a mirror finish as with the heater block.

Both my resistors failed rather quickly, so I took advantage of the downtime to do this in hope that my next set of resistors might not fail as quickly and for the chance of improving heating performance. I have no data to support any of this, it takes less time to assume. The process is simple: put sandpaper on the flattest surface you can find, such as a piece of glass, and start sanding. Ideally you want to work with the small increments. I started with 150 grit dry sandpaper, then moved to wet sandpaper to 320, 400, 600, and 1500. It would have been better to move up to 2000 in increments of 100, but I'm impatient so I went with what I found at the local hardware store. Don't forget to use soapy water when wet sanding. The next step to maximize thermal transfer would be to use a thermal interface material, but the only one I could find (Red Ice 600 series from Timtronics) isn't available for sale to the public, so Makerbot Industries (or some other biz) should totally look into that. Final result: room temperature to 225 c in about 8 minutes, which is much faster than zero or one functional resistor. As I said already, I have no idea if it's actually any faster/better otherwise.

comments.text: Is this better than using the thermal heat sink paste compound that Radio Shack and other places sell?
comments.author: Mjolnir

comments.text: It's better in the sense that typical thermal interface material, made for IC heat transfer (ie Arctic Silver), is not formulated to handle the temperatures involved here (see Ed's comment below). As I mentioned in the instructions here, a suitable TIM exists, and certainly would help heat transfer, but cannot be easily obtained. At any rate, when printing ABS with an aluminum build plate, the hot end is no longer the bottleneck. And, fwiw, it seems that one of my resistors has burnt out again, much faster this time, giving me less confidence that improved heat transfer might extend their life; I reckon manufacturing variances will have a much greater impact in that regard.
I did this as well, after buying a cheap lapping kit (i.e. a dozen small pieces of wet and dry from 400 grit to 2500 grit) and I agree with dreameredeemer that the resistors really aren't very flat.
comments.author: Robot_Guy

comments.text: Polishing the interface should reduce the thermal coefficient between the resistor and the Thermal Core. That reduces the maximum resistor temperature, which is a Very Good Thing. Nice work!
comments.author: ednisley

comments.text: Looks like a good idea will try it out when my resistors fail
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I had the same idea. I figured I'd do that and use the anti-sieze compound as a really basic thermal paste. I got that idea from Ed Nisley and one of his posts about testing the resistors.

This is a ping pong ball that I wrote my name on using the the Eggbot.

First, I made a file on Adobe Illustrator.
I then used the text tool to write my name using the Pupcat font.
I then used the symbol tool to make the paint splatters on the ball.
After I was done, I converted the file to an SVG and opened it on Inkscape.
After setting up the ball in the Eggbot machine, I set the pen up position to 84, and the pen down position to 78.
Then I pressed apply and the eggbot made by ping pong ball.

This is a bracket for the Mendelmax 2. I recommend printing both in ABS or the bracket in ABS and the shroud in flex ;). I usually super glue them together, I'll get around to making a hinge at some point. I print the fan bracket with support using S3D. If the shroud is to close to the print then just use a few washers to heighten it. Also, be aware of your temperature and fan speed. Too high of a fan speed can influence your temperature too much on some prints. Released through my company Northern Layers: http://northernlayers.com

title: Diamond Lattice Model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Diamond is the hardest known material on the Mohs scale of mineral hardness. Diamond lattice has face centered cubic structure with 4 atoms in the inside. Carbon atoms bond in tetrahedral configuration with 4 neighboring atoms at angle 109.5 degrees, with length 1.54 Angstroms. Silicon, germanium, and gallium arsenide, some of the most important materials in modern technology, have the same crystal structure as diamond.   
This model is a part of a unit cell featuring 14 atoms and 16 bonds. For educational setting or just for fun, diamond lattice is a nice model to have on your desktop! But be warned, taking the support off may take some time and patience!

My wife asked me to fix electric compost machine. I found the gear on the motor shaft was worn out badly . So I made same one as possible as I could.
The tooth wasn't perfect shape but it worked fine and I could finally made my wife happy with my bot. This is the first time that my wife thank to my new toy.
I designed this gear by OpenScad as parametric gear ( still learning though).

Here is a project of mines to create a hacker version of the beastgrip. The big change is really the handle of the device where I put holes to allow me to mount extra things inside and outside the handle. Also added to holes to the back of the clamp so I can possible mount a backup power bank that I can have connected to the phone to extend the time I can use it. Just like the beastgrip you can screw in 37mm lenses to use with you're phone. I actually used a lens filter plus 3d printed a clamp to attach it to the rig. Works very well to replicate this feature of the beastgrip. If you do try to build this, get the cheapest filter you can. The quality of the glass isn't important, what you really want is the metal threading. Thats about it. I have some ideas for the second version. Sketching some ideas of creating the rig a bit differently. Also will attempt doing something with thumb screws so it'll be easier to put the 3 main parts together. Also want channels or some way to easily run the headphone wire in the rig. So all in all, a good start but far from where I want to be. I modified an open source camera app to use the earbud buttons but because of some issues I'm thinking about creating my own Android Camera app specifically to use with this rig. I've done a simple camera app before on android for work, so I'm confident I can put together a fun open source app for this project. I'll begin work on MK2 once I finish my other project, a gimbal camera stabilizer. As you can tell, most of my projects are geared around photographing :) Small Youtube Video about it.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g6gWaz9hLuY Freecad source included.

Items
  • 37mm Lens Filter (get the cheapest one possible)
  • Two 1/4 - 4 Inch Bolts and size nuts
  • Four #6-32 3 inch flat head screw (lowes and amazon has them)
  • Four #6-32 2 inch screws (2 flat / 2 round head)
  • Two #6-32 3/4 inch round head screws
  • Quite a few #6-32 nuts
  • Two compression springs

Part of our '2D to 3D' project

My 3D printing class was asked to choose a project that was interesting to us. I chose portion control, and after doing some research, I decided on designing kitchen utensils that would control your portion size.  
-Nat from Yellow Chickens

All of my designs are based on the theory that if you take smaller bites, and therefore eat slower, you will get full faster and eat less over all. The idea of these utensils is to give you smaller bites or to limit the size that your bite can be. Fork:
Design: The fork has a small hinge at the front of the handle. After it is printed, you must glue a piece of rubber band over the hinge so that it will go back after being bent.
Idea: The idea for this fork is that if you try to pick something up that is too heavy (and therefore big), the joint will bend and the piece will fall off the fork. Knife:
Design: The knife has two blades in front of the handle, one on the left and one on the right. The blades are serrated so that it is possible to cut tougher foods.
Idea: With this knife, when you try to cut a large piece, it will be cut in two and you will eat the full piece more slowly because of this. Spoon With Hole:
Design: This is just a regular spoon which has a small hole in the bottom.
Idea: When you eat soup, by the time the spoon reaches your mouth, some soup has already drained out of the whole.
Alternate uses: If you like your cereal without milk, you can use this spoon to drain the milk before eating each bite.
CAUTION: Highly Drippy! False-Bottom Spoon:
Design: This spoon is completely ordinary except that it is shallower than a normal spoon (more of the spoon is filled in than normal).
Idea: The point of this spoon is just that you get less soup per bite. Straw:
Design: This straw has two small flaps inside the main tube to restrict the flow of liquid.
Idea: The idea for the straw is that the two flaps will restrict the flow of liquid, and will slow down the drinker.

description.text:
Mew Mew is a modular desk tidy system so you can keep you pencils, pens, paper-clips and other office supply goodies neat and tidy on your desk.
The system allows you to combine the hexagon based Mew Mew in different ways; each Honey Pot slides together simply and easily.

Three .stl files are included for the basic, most useful heights: 20mm, 40mm and 80mm.  When printed you'll probably get some strands between some of the gaps which will need to be filed away. I find it's best to print this without a raft.
I've also included the Google Sketchup file of the base 20mm model. With this you can pull or push the height really easily to exactly fit your needs. Of course would love to see people improve  the design too!

description.text: Mount Sinabung is a stratovolcano in North Sumatra, Indonesia. Constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 0.6 million polygons). It was made using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

title: LH Footrest extension for Mitsubishi Pajero NW model

description.text:
MK II - added herringbone pattern for extra grip.  
The existing LH footrest in the Mitsubishi NW Pajero sits an uncomfortable 40 mm further away from the left foot than the brake pedal.  My father and I designed this Thing in Autodesk 123D to balance up the foot position.  The footrest is affixed to the existing foam underlay using four wood screws.

Printed in ABS on a Makerbot Replicator 1 Dual at 90/150 mm/s, 0.2 mm layer thickness and 2 shells, with 10% infill, raft and supports.  The small supports are only for the counterbore assemblies.  The top face of the footrest is (amazingly) self-supporting during printing.  Took about 4 hours to print.

title: Ramps 1.4, Arduino MEGA, LCD adapter slide box with optional twin fan ducts

description.text:
This little gem was inspired by a ton of variations of ramps boxes i found through the search function... I was looking to keep my drivers cool and keep little fingers (like those of my kids) and teeth (like those of my cat) from touching the wires...Plus with the optional ducting, it has a cool look to it...everything should print as needed...i have not yet printed it because my nozzle went tits up as did my PSU (china made crap)...but i have a dedicated 12v33a supply on the way and a E3D v6 to get still so ill post pics when done...the variations i pulled from all had been proven to be good prints, so it should be fine...
update:
id alos like to add, the LCD itself doesnt mount to the box, but it has opening and room for the LCD adapter...Also, the fans are 40mm...
update#2: E3dv6 hotend on order...woo hoo....

title: Automatic Platform Leveling and Z Calibration made SUPER EASY

description.text:
Well nearly automatic; it doesn't get much easier than this. This is for a Thing-O-Matic, but there's no reason you can't apply the same principle to any bot. This is simply a Z-Min endstop that works and is simple to build. Many thanks owed to DammitCoetzee, who thought up some even more clever directions to take this that I've not yet implemented. And many many thanks to Worksofman for the awesome aluminum plate. YOU HAVE TO SEE THIS VIDEO TO BELIEVE!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UdDoe01l6WU UPDATE! OMG! FORGET THAT VIDEO! WATCH THIS VIDEO INSTEAD! IT WILL EXPLODE YOUR HEAD! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XRt436ihaxw How many times have you had to recalibrate your Z? Not only do I never have to calibrate it again, I never have to go back and regenerate gcode if it changes. My gcode automatically takes into account the current Zmin/max. IS THIS AWESOME? SEE INSTRUCTIONS PART TWO BELOW. Here's a bonus, earlier video of me using the control pad to test it - trying to put it through the platform multiple times:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZF10jI0xSao Some notes:
  • Doesn't require any firmware mods or changes, unlike the ESTOP.
  • If you are using the ABP belt, you can probably still use this outside its margins.
  • I haven't printed on my fancy new alu plate, and I will cover it in kapton before I do. Of course I will cut small holes to use for this leveling technique -- and I also intend to test whether the system will punch through the kapton and trigger the stop, or not. -- UPDATE, it does not, unless the head is also moving in X+Y at the same time So don't count on this to SAVE YOU but DO use it to calibrate in test points you have removed the kapton! Video of punch fail here (not very interesting): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7x6tTmTuSH0
  • The SEXY and GORGEOUS alu plate was sent to me courtesy of Worksofman, whose website has some of the most fantastic metal sculpture I've ever seen: http://www.worksofman.com/sculpture ... but you may have to find your own source for the plate; I think it was a one-time deal. :)

KNOWN REQUIREMENTS: 2 10,000 ohm resistors.
2 longish bits of wire (red and black would be nice)
2 female pin connectors of any type (my photos show I used a 4-socket female header to make it nice)
  • some kind of wire insulator; kapton, electrical tape, heat shrink tubing...
    • STUFF I'M USING I HAVEN'T TESTED WITHOUT BUT YOU MIGHT NOT /NEED/ AS SUCH:
    6 short compression springs to fit the bolts on your build platform
    4 long compression springs to fit in place of the spacers on your hot end.
    1 TOTALLY SEXY alu plate with countersunk bolts. When this is activated, it seems instant and if the springs are adding any benefit, I'm unable to see it. But I don't intend the trouble of taking them off just to let ya'll know if it works OK without. My guess is it does. The same goes for the aluminum plate. The previous thing used the heat spreader and worked just as well contacting it. But I'm never taking this thing off; the countersunk bolts are awesome. HOW TO PUT IT TOGETHER:
    (See photos!) 1) Crimp/solder one end of the resistors each into a female pin.
    2) Solder the other end of one to the black wire, and the other to the red wire. Insulate the connections.
    3) Install them in a housing - or just plug them straight into the port. See photos.
    4) Strip a small amount of insulation off the ends of the wires.
    5) Red wire goes to the build platform heat spreader or SEXY ALU PLATE, and black wire to the head - wherever you like as long as it conducts!
    6) If your platform is already covered in kapton, scrape off a tiny amount where you plan to perform the procedure, so it can easily contact the heat spreader or alu plate.
    7) TEST IT... use a bit of wire to connect your platform to the nozzle and try to move it Z-; if it moves, check everything and try again.
    8) Open the Thing-O-Matic Z Calibration Script as you normally would, but change this line:
    M01 (Turn the threaded rod... etc
    to this:
    G161 Z F500 (Boldly go where no one has gone before!)
    9) Move your platform so the print head is aligned with your chosen test point, then... run it! Keep a finger on the power button just in case. Good luck! My personal recommendation would be to use the ESTOP and this both, and unplug the ESTOP while you are calibrating, so it does not shut things down. The problem with just using a Z-Min for /protection/ is it won't work well; the head will contact the plate and Z will stop, but X+Y will continue to move, which may (or may not?) scrape the plate. The ESTOP shuts down /all/ axis, hard. INSTRUCTIONS PART 2: Watch the head-exploding youtube video at the top, then contemplate this gcode while you put the bits and ends back together! : ( begin homing )
    G162 Z F500 (home Z axis maximum)
    G161 X Y F2500 (home XY axes minimum)
    G92 X0 Y0 (set current position = 0)
    G1 X1 Y30 (goto 1,30 Z test point)
    G161 Z F500 (home z minimum)
    G92 Z0 ( Set Z axis minimum )
    G92 X-50 Y-50 (set zero for X and Y)
    G1 X0 Y0 Z40.0 F3300.0 (move to waiting position)
    ( end homing )

The fancy bounce in your video is your gcode telling the Z-axis  to go 'UP' home which is the Z-max. Yes?

I made this cable guide to keep the cable bundle that comes down from the top of the i3v to the X-carriage from getting caught in-between the X-carriage and the home switch while homing. Also to just keep the cable out of the way in general. I attach it to the top of the printer with a few cable ties and then attach the cable assembly with another cable tie or two. I will upload some pictures of it installed when I get a chance. I originally drew this to be printed on its side but I ended up printing it with the arch up and support material under the bridge shape. It worked out pretty good but it may be better printing on its side.

I originally drew this to be printed on its side but I ended up printing it with the arch up and support material under the bridge shape. It worked out pretty good but it may be better printing on its side. If you want to print it flat 12.15° will have both ends touching the bed. The green image shows how I printed with support.

title: Raspberry Pi 2 B+ mounting cage for Top Hat DIN Rail / Cap Rail / Hutschiene 35mm

description.text:
This is a bare holder to mount your Raspberry Pi B+/2 on so it stands level on the table even with mounted heatsink on the bottom. You can use my Top Hat Rail / Cap Rail mount base plate (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:684759) to easily mount your Raspberry Pi into your control cabinet. There are two versions of the holder:
  • One with a flat base for simple table stand or for glue to the flat Cap Rail mount base plate
  • One with clips to snap on the version of my Cap Rail mount that has notches
    • Thread the holes with M2.6 thread cutter before mounting the Pi on it. Hint: The clips snaps really tight on the notches of the Cap Rail mount. I carefully bent the clips a little bit before putting these two together. You have to use quite a lot force to snap them together. But the PLA I used for printing was flexible enough. Once snapped together it is not designed to be put apart again. Have fun with it :)

author: Bash-T

description.text:
My version of blokkendoos knob.
His didn't fit my M8 screws. Maybe his are different. Don't know. This Hand Knob fits screws with a M8 thread and a head size of about ~12.8 mm. Design came out with a really tight fit on my Printrbot Metal Simple.
Feel free to message me if it doesn't fit.

Printed with Printrbot Simple Metal:
  • 0.2mm layer height
  • 2 ouline/perimeter shells
  • 25% Infill
  • 25% support for the hole
  • black PLA at 185°C

comments.text: First off thanks to all involved, these are handy to have around. When I tried this on my Prusa i3 I had a few issues. About midway through the print (ABS) as the hex section stops and the through-hole starts, the filament got all noodley and crazy. Eventually remembering it was supposed to be making a cylinder, it trued up and al was fine in the end. Rafts were off so maybe that was it - not sure. Also the description had me thinking they would be an interference fit or at least snug. Nope. Mine were actually a bit loose (on garden-variety m8 bolts). If you turn the knob over the bolt falls out. Anyway, the knobs are super heavy-duty and very strong.
comments.author: randeals

title: 4 channel relay mounting cage for Top Hat DIN Rail / Cap Rail / Hutschiene 35mm / Arduino

description.text:
This is a bare holder to mount a 4 channel relay on so it stands level on the table without the risk of short circuit. I designed it for this kind of 4 channel relay: http://www.ebay.de/itm/221584819206 You can use my Top Hat Rail / Cap Rail mount base plate (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:684759) to easily mount your relay into your control cabinet. There are two versions of the holder:
  • One with a flat base for simple table stand or for glue to the flat Cap Rail mount base plate
  • One with clips to snap on the version of my Cap Rail mount that has notches
    • Thread the holes with M3 thread cutter before mounting the Pi on it. The distance of the mounting holes are 38mm x 68.3mm Hint: The clips snaps really tight on the notches of the Cap Rail mount. I carefully bent the clips a little bit before putting these two together. You have to use quite a lot force to snap them together. But the PLA I used for printing was flexible enough. Once snapped together it is not designed to be put apart again. Have fun with it :)

title: Prusa i3 printable Extruder mount with bed leveling

description.text:
This is a printable direct drive extruder mount for Prusa i3 that contains auto bed level sensing using the extruder tip.
It holds a NEMA 17 motor.
Also: there is a mount plate for a dragchain.

Printed out of PLA. The main mount should be printed with the back to the build plate and with support. The optical sensor can be screwed directly into the print. Assembly:
1) fix mount to your x axis
2) fix the bottom and top plate to the motor with zip ties
3) connect the bottom plate to the mount with a long M3 bolt
4) fix the photo sensor to the mount with two M3 screws
5) fix the sensor fin to the top plate with some glue

Modelo topográfico del monte Everest en Nepal. Creado a partir de datos GMRT descargados desde el servicio web:
http://www.marine-geo.org/tools/maps_grids.php Para la obtención del modelo STL, se ha usado DEMto3d, una herramienta útil y fácil de usar para covertir MDE (modelos digitales de elevaciones) en modelos STL, listos para imprimir en 3D. DEMto3D está disponible en la siguiente dirección: http://www.demto3d.com/
DEMto3D funciona como una extensión disponibles para los softwares SIG gratuitos Kosmo (http://www.opengis.es/) y QGIS (http://www.qgis.org/en/site/)

Topography model of the Mount Everest in Nepal. Created from GMRT data downloaded from http://www.marine-geo.org/tools/maps_grids.php To obtain the STL model, I used DEMto3d, an easy and useful tool to convert DEM data to STL models ready to print. This tool is available in the next link http://www.demto3d.com/
DEMto3D is a plugin available for free GIS software Kosmo (http://www.opengis.es/) and QGIS (http://www.qgis.org/en/site/)

title: Air Hockey Robot (an OPEN SOURCE 3D printer hack)

description.text:
Based on the idea of using standard RepRap 3D printer parts : NEMA17 stepper motors, drivers, Arduino Mega, RAMPS, belts , bearings, rods, printed pieces … I started to develop the project. The main advantage of using these parts is that they are cheap and easily available. A fully functional robot to play with! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CjzSeOg8oTs

title: Replicator 2 extruder replacement with no overheating issues v2

description.text: Trying to improve the extruder mod v1 loaded last month http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:60574 I decided to make a new and cheap design using a 9 mm diameter bearing and one clothespin that everybody has at home. The spring of the clothespin has the same internal diameter than the extruder default bolts si it is "perfect.

Print all the pieces and keep in mind that the small piece that goes into the gear is a small piece and some printers will print it bigsmaller that design so maybe you have to adjust the tube diameter.  
Cut one bended part of the clothespin to fit it in the extruder back piece and bend the other leg a little nearer to spring to adjust the turn radio (in my case 2-3 millimeters are enough).  
Put the smallest piece into the bended leg of spring and insert the bearing then put the st into the extruder rear part.  
To mount the front part you only have to rotate 90 degree, push against the rear part of the extruder and rotate he front until all pieces are aligned. Then mount into the motor.

comments.text: This is interesting; how well does it work? Have you tried any of the other minimalist extruder mods out there?

description.text:
Bequi is an jointed robot 23cm high, has 16 joints. Among her favorite hobbies include to become a support for mobile and be the star of Stop Motion movies. - See more at: http://diwo.bq.com/en/bequi-the-first-printdoll-from-bq/ She are joined by elastic cords.
Joining Bequi: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P-aYNbkBm-Y Author: https://www.soniaverdu.es

Among the files to download, there are two heads to choose from, and there are also two chests, one with the logo of bequi and one without logo to customize.
No need material support should be needed. But recommend adhesion platform The elastic cord that best fits the figurine is 2,5mm in diameter. Layer height(mm): 0.15
botton/top, Shell thickness(mm): 1.2 It is important for delicate parts of the hands
Fill density%: 15
Print speed(mm/s): 40
Interior Support : none
Printed pla 210º (c)

description.text:
For spools less than 75mm in diameter.
Uses 608 bearings
Zip-tie arms to the frame If you appreciate the effort that went into this design then make a donation by purchasing here: https://www.redpah.com/product/1356/prusa-i3-spool-holder
Its something simple to put in the kitchen.

A large tree for digibird toys. I have designed this large tree to mount our digibirds. The tree is printed in several parts and can put together resulting in a 40x40x40 cm object. The only drawback: you need 7 digibirds ;) The design was made using Fusion 360 and printed on an Ultimaker O+. See http://youtu.be/5Sq-bM0AXUo

Printing suggestions:

  • I used colorfabb PLA chocolate brown for the branches and (naturally) leaf green for the leafs.

  • The root and supports were printed at 100 mm/s (210 degrees) without support or brim. The large branches I printed using a brim to keep them standing up during printing. The whole tree can be joined mechanically.

  • For the leafs I used a brim & supports in order to be able to print them (at 50 mm/s, 190 degrees). They come at several sizes and can be mechanically joined with the knot. However, for the smallest leafs I finally ended up glueing them together with the knot as the part became to flimsy.

I don't want to use the camera joystick on the skycontroler to pan the camera. Instead I prefer to pan the entire drone. But the sensitivity of the joystick makes me pan even if I just want to tilt. Hence this little thing that makes that the joystick can only move up and down.
I used little patches of double sided adhesive tape on the 4 corners to attach it.

This carriage allows to block the strap easily and without using clamping collars. Therefore, there is no wasted place taken by the strap attachment and the carriage has a wider sliding range.
There are three bearing housing which is sufficient for the linear guide while keeping an isostatic assembly.
It's recommended to insert the nut in internal housing of the part to obtain a cleaner installation (enclosed nut). So you have to write a pause in the G-code (read instructions). Ce chariot permet de bloquer la courroie facilement et sans l'aide de colliers de serrage. Par conséquent, il n'y a pas de perte d'espace sur les cotés du charriot à cause de la fixation de la courroie et le chariot a une plus large étendue de mouvement.
Il y a trois logements pour mettre les roulements ce qui est suffisant pour le guidage linéaire tout en gardant un ensemble isostatique.
Il est recommandé d'insérer l'écrou dans le logement interne de la partie principale pour obtenir une installation propre. Pour cela, vous devez écrire une pause dans le G-code (lire les instructions).

As shown in pictures, You should search in the preview of Repetier the last opened layer of nut housing, then write a "@pause" in the g-code with a rise of Z axis to free the part .
When the printer reaches these lines, the pause command stops automatically the printing and moves the z axis up. You can therefore insert the nut and then manually make a restart of the printing. You can heat the nut before fitting it. Comme indiqué dans les photos, je recommande de rechercher dans l'aperçu de Repetier la dernière couche qui laisse la cage de l'écrou ouverte, puis d'écrire "@pause" dans le g-code suivi d'une hausse de l'axe Z pour libérer la pièce :
Lorsque l'imprimante atteint ces lignes, la commande de pause arrête automatiquement l'impression et déplace l'axe z vers le haut. A ce moment, vous pouvez insérer l'écrou dans son logement et ensuite faire manuellement un redémarrage de l'impression. Je conseille de chauffer l'écrou (briquet ou fer à souder) avant de le monter pour faciliter l'insertion.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/26BVBRk9s7C

This is a derivative of Tinkering's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4526 with the endstop interface and the LED's removed (for now) using the http://www.robotshop.com/pololu-8v-35v-2a-single-bipolar-stepper-motor-driver-w-regulators.html . This board is designed to be easy to etch at home using the laser printer method so it can be made at home. I decided to make this guy because i fried one of my motor controllers by accident and the replacements have a 3 week lead time. Everything needed to make this can be picked up from radio shack in exception to some of the connectors. If you want micro-stepping (1/16), and want to learn how to make your own PCB, this thing is for you.
  • Will be finishing write up soon!

Etching:
  • Clean your PCB using steel wool and becareful not to leave finger prints, set up 2 bins large enough for the PCB and fill one with water. Also, begin heating the iron (max setting).
  • Print the pdf on glossy paper using a laser printer. Many ,tutorials are available online.
  • Iron the glossy paper onto the pcb. This part is a bit tricky, you don't want to iron it too long or it will be difficult to remove the paper. Again watch a few videos in youtube before beginning.
  • Put the pcb with paper in the water bin. Let it soak for a few minutes and begin rubbing the outer layers of the glossy paper. Once you can see the circuitry it is enough, but the bath will take longer and possibly 2 baths required with a clean in between.
  • Place PCB in the empty bin, and pour your etching solution in there so it covers the board. The time in the bath may vary from 2m-50m+ (alot) depending on how clean your board is, the potency of your etching solution, and the temperature of the solution.
  • Clean off your board when it is finished. All of the exposed copper should have disappeared.
  • Drill your holes (I used carbide tips i bought from Harbor Freight)
  • Clean off the laser laser toner using acetone and your steel wool.
  • Solder all your components. (resistor direction does not matter, capacitor direction does! **The middle capacitor is in the opposite direction as the other two caps!.)
  • I used a multi-meter checking resistance and a magnifying glass to see if there are any short circuits.
  • Plug in and test!

It's my first upload, but it's a filament guide and cleaner. Took about 30 minutes to print on the stock Printrbot 1405. It connects on your Z axis bars. The long notched end goes at that back, feed the filament through the first eyelet, fold a small piece of paper towel or put a sponge into the arch, pass the filament through it out the front of the arch and into the second eyelet. Put a little piece of painters tape on the bottom half of the back of the arch to keep the paper towel in. Move the filament back and forth make sure it's not getting caught anywhere and not pulling the towel/sponge out the front or the back of the arch, then feed it into the extruder. That's all.

title: Logitech C170/C270 webcam bracket for Mendel90

description.text:
Finally got round to uploading this.  
Simple bracket for mounting a Logitech C170 or C270 webcam onto a Mendel90, using an existing screw so no additional mounting holes need to be drilled.  
I've got mine connected to my OctoPi (Raspberry Pi running OctoPrint) so that I can monitor my print jobs remotely.

My original SCAD is parametric, so I can produce a bracket of any height (the gantry pattern is auto-generated). Unfortunately I make extensive use of my own library of OpenSCAD routines which the Customizer isn't able to use, so I've just included the two most useful heights. 100mm is the standard height, and gives a nice low-level shot of the bed.
130mm is slightly higher and gives a better perspective - useful if you tend to print large things.

title: Portable Thermoelectric Motor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple design part to one of my DIY.
Full description here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Portable-Airflow-Companion/ What does it do? It converts heat energy into kinetic energy, looks nice and sounds awesome! It uses a thermoelectric generator module (TEG) to power a motor with a fan. The heat source (candle) heat up the lower aluminium plate => creates a temperature difference over the module => generates electricity to the motor => increases air flow through heat sink => increases temperature difference => more power. Without the fan it would eventually stop generating power since the heat sink would get almost same temperature as the plate. Almost any heat source with enough temperature can be used to power the motor and this makes this small device easy and fun to experiment with. As seen in the video it´s powered from fire, hot water, food, and even used to cool a computer processor. The latter is an idea I had when i created my first build in 2013 and people said to me it cannot be done. It can and it´s stable for normal use but with further optimizations it could probably be even better. I don't think it can replace a regular CPU cooler but as it uses no electricity from the computer it´s somewhat environmental friendly. It require few parts, easy to build and you do not need any knowledge about electronics. You just need some mechanical tools for cutting, drilling and polishing the aluminium. http://youtu.be/aeeq-gKX01o

For design purpose you can print this special part if you have a printer and transparent filament like T-glase. I used a wanhao duplicator 4x printer and simplify 3D software. Printer settings: Layer height: 0.37mm (single outline corkscrew method (vase mode)
Shells: 1
Infill: 0
Top and bottom layers: 0
Extrusion multiplier: 1.15
Extrustion width: 0.5mm
Speed: 600mm/min (10mm/s)
Temp extruder: 235C
Temp bed: 80C

The little case provides a fine place for your arduino uno. You can also attach a small breadboard. Then breadboard and arduino uno are  stabilized and you can start prototyping your next arduino project.

I printed the thing with my Kossel Mini (and Simplify3D version 2.2.2 ). You can use M3 (6mm) bolts to tighten the arduino uno. That's all. I use the following settings:
  • nozzel diameter 0.4
  • extrusion width 0.4
  • layer height 0.3
  • outline/perimeter shells 3
  • heat bed at 70º celsius
  • extruder at 220º celsius
  • PLA filament

This is an easy to print, easy to use tool to help with assembling Traxxas 5347 ball joints, used in many Delta printers.  
The pictures show how to use it.  
The steel ball piece is guided by a 30 mm M3 screw and should snap in place with a firm press of the conical pusher.  
OpenSCAD source is included so the thing can be remixed if needed.
Printed in PLA with 35% infill. Requires one 30mm or 40mm M3 screw.
